data.title: My magnificent seven: The outrageous memoirs of Hollywood legend Robert Vaughn
data.meta_description: ROBERT VAUGHN, one of film and TV's biggest stars for 50 years, has written an irreverent and revealing book about life and love among Hollywood's outrageous A-listers.
data.text:
From being one of The Magnificent Seven to playing Napoleon Solo in The Man From U.N.C.L.E and appearing as a legendary conman in BBC1's Hustle, ROBERT VAUGHN has remained one of film and TV's biggest stars for 50 years. Now, at last, he has written an irreverent and revealing book about life and love among Hollywood's outrageous A-listers ...

Guns for hire: Vaughn, McQueen and Brynner on the set of the iconic Western

How Judy Garland made a grab for me

Someone once said Hollywood is like High School but with money. I agree. And in the late Fifties and early Sixties, as my TV and movie roles and fees got bigger, I found myself becoming one of the big men on campus, with my choice of the prettiest cheerleaders - and a few others, too.

One evening I went to a charity event at the Beverly Hilton hotel where the star guests were Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton.

I arrived alone, but as I made my way to my table, I heard a voice calling: 'Robert! Robert! Over here!'

It was Mark Herron, an actor and old college friend, who was accompanied by Judy Garland, well oiled and wearing, for some reason, a plaster cast on her right hand. Judy insisted I sit with them.

As she carried on drinking, she grew increasingly boisterous. By the time Taylor and Burton arrived, she was bubbling with manic energy.

Seeing Taylor, she yelled: 'Here she comes, Miss MGM T**s!' followed by, 'and look who's with her: that no-talent, nasal-voiced, pockmarked son-of-a-bitch from Wales!' Every word was loud and clear.

Then, as the orchestra began playing slow dance music, Judy got excited. 'Robert, you must dance with me!'

Mark, who would later become her fourth husband, pleaded: 'Please, Robert, maybe she'll calm down - or better yet, pass out.'

Judy and I made our way to the dance floor. Within a minute, I felt an unexpected pressure in a delicate spot. Judy had gone for the Vaughn family jewels with her right hand, cast and all. My first thought was: 'God! I hope those photographers don't see this!'

No such luck. I was blinded by flashbulbs. Fortunately no photo was published, but it was far from my last scrape in the crazy world of Hollywood.

Vaughn rubbed shoulders with a garrulous Judy Garland and the imposing director Cecil B. DeMille

Cecil B. DeMille had me covered in a fake tan

I'd arrived there, aged 19, from Minneapolis, the scion of a theatrical family. My mother, a stage actress, wanted me to act and the thespian bug had bitten early.

Like many roles, my first screen appearance had come about in a hurry.

In the mid-Fifties, a college chum heard about auditions for extras in the celebrated director Cecil B. DeMille's remake of The Ten Commandments. I got to the audition within 20 minutes of hearing about it.

The film provided two contrasting weeks' work: the first as a Jew in the golden calf scene and the second as an Arab in a chariot. I made $1,000: good money compared with the $35 a week I was paid as a part-time truck driver while studying at college.

For the first week, I'd had my entire body sprayed with fake tan every morning while wearing only a jockstrap. This was the studio's idea of what it would take to make me look Jewish. I was then fitted with a tiny tan loincloth.

One day, around 1pm, DeMille, by then in his 70s and with little hair, was up on a high crane.

With him was a fellow whose only job was to anticipate when DeMille wanted to speak to the cast. He would then thrust a slender gold microphone in front of the great man.

When DeMille spotted a young girl extra talking when she should have been silent, he sent an assistant to walk over to the girl and point at her.

DeMille then said: 'Young lady, tell us what you are saying that is so important that you have to talk when we are preparing to shoot?'

Terrified, she couldn't answer. DeMille asked again. Still no answer. When he asked a third time, she responded, barely whispering: 'I was just saying I wonder when the old bald-headed guy is going to call lunch.'

There was a painful pause. The hundreds of people working on the scene, including me, looked downward, riven with fear for the poor girl.

DeMille slowly brought the gold microphone to his lips, paused and then barked: 'Lunch! One hour.'

With Paul Newman in The Young Philadelphians

Comparing pistols on The Magnificent Seven

In 1960 I was signed up just as quickly for The Magnificent Seven, along with James Coburn and Charles Bronson, after a strike threatened to shut production if casting wasn't completed by a certain Friday.

The director had seen me in my first big movie, The Young Philadelphians, and by then I'd done TV shows such as Dragnet and Gunsmoke. That, it appeared, was good enough for me to play alongside Steve McQueen and Yul Brynner.

Steve was intensely competitive. It wasn't enough just to be successful - he had to be more successful than anyone he saw as a rival. So it was inevitable there would be a showdown between him and Brynner.

The pecking order for The Magnificent Seven was established early on during shooting in Cuernavaca, Mexico.

Brynner, who'd won an Oscar for The King And I, was the biggest star - aloof and distant - and accordingly stayed in a private house. The rest of us made do with a motel.

The rivalry between McQueen and Brynner was clear from the start. Steve started knocking on my door around 6.30am, an hour before we were due on set. Our conversations were always along the same lines.

'Man,' he would say in that husky whisper, 'did you see Brynner's gun on the set yesterday?'

'I can't say I noticed it, Steve.' 'You didn't notice it? It has a f*****g pearl handle, for God's sake. He shouldn't have a gun like that. It's too f*****g fancy. Nobody's gonna look at anything else with that goddam gun in the picture.'

Of course, what Steve meant was that nobody would be looking at Steve McQueen.

'Maybe you should talk to the director,' I'd suggest. Steve just shook his head - obviously I was too naive to comprehend the depth and villainy of the conspiracy against him - and left.

Two days later, there was another early-morning knock on the door. 'Did you see the size of Brynner's horse? It's goddam gigantic.'

This time I had noticed. 'Actually, Steve, I've got the biggest horse of the Seven.'

McQueen shook his head. 'I don't give a f*** about your horse,' he replied. 'It's Brynner's horse I'm worried about.'

How I escaped a Mexican madam with Steve McQueen

On Good Friday, work on The Magnificent Seven shut down in Mexico. Brad Dexter, one of the Seven and a buddy of Frank Sinatra's, suggested Steve and I join him in a visit to what he called 'one of the finest brothels in North America'.

Having spent nearly a decade wandering LA's Sunset Strip, I'd met many ladies of the evening. I considered many of them friends, and had made it a rule not to do business with them. But I decided to tag along.

Brad directed our taxi driver to a lavish high-walled hacienda in a quiet district of Mexico City, where the blonde madam welcomed us like visiting dignitaries at an embassy cocktail party.

Rounds of margaritas appeared, along with beautifully coiffed and gowned ladies. Brad left with a pair of dark-haired beauties as still more margaritas arrived.

With the light slowly dimming in the room and in my head, the madam announced it was time to make a selection.

There were seven girls in the room. In stumbling Spanish, Steve told the madam that all seven should stay 'because we are the Magnificent Seven'.

It seemed to me that we were just two very drunk Americans, and I wasn't feeling very magnificent, but I did not object to Steve's gluttonous suggestion.

I was flush with both pesos and dollars, having been too sick with an upset stomach in Cuernavaca to spend my daily allowance. So Steve and I adjourned to a room with many large pillows and the seven women.

If you've never experienced sex for seven, you're undoubtedly interested in the salacious details. I can only say that, due to the tequila, we did more laughing than anything else.

Near midnight, I recalled that filming was scheduled for the next day. I said to Steve: 'Let's pay our bill and get out of here.'

I was yet to hear about Steve's famous habit of not carrying money. He replied: 'Hey, man, could you loan me some dinero?'

The bill came to something like $700 - pretty big money in the Sixties. I had about 400 on me, along with several hundred pesos, and I offered the whole wad to the madam.

'I'm paying for three and a half senoritas, including tip,' I said, hoping for a laugh.

The madam didn't smile. Instead, she snapped her fingers and a huge hombre entered the room. Fixing a hostile glare on me and Steve, he reached out, grabbed my money, and asked: 'How you plan to pay the rest?'

I smiled at Steve. He smiled at the hombre. The hombre ... he no smile back.

Suddenly a light seemed to dawn in Steve's alcoholic haze. Pulling out his wallet, he produced a Diners Club booklet containing coupons for use at restaurants. 'How about these?' he asked, pathetically. The hombre moved towards us. Several more mean-looking Mexicans materialised.

On cue, Steve and I spun around and pushed through some swing doors. Steve dashed towards the right, while I ran left down a long hall ending in French doors, and vaulted over a balcony.

I landed on moist grass, sprang up and ran to the high wall surrounding the villa grounds, where I scrambled up a trellis and flung myself on to the edge of the wall.

Eyeing the 12ft drop to the street below, I saw two bulky Mexicans standing there as if on guard. I dropped to the ground, expecting to be apprehended if not beaten to a pulp.

I stood up and smiled wanly at the two men. They merely smiled, remarked, 'Buenos noches,' and strolled away.

The next morning, Steve arrived on the set 45 minutes late and badly hungover.

He'd talked his way out of the brothel by promising to pay the balance in full and to tip generously. His years on the street had served him well.

Hollywood heroes: Robert Vaughn clowns around with Man From U.N.C.L.E. co-star David McCallum, left, at an awards ceremony

I had to put up an electric fence to keep the girls out

The role that changed my life, Napoleon Solo in The Man From U.N.C.L.E., also came about in a hurry.

A friend and I had hit Sunset Boulevard and picked up a couple of floozies. I didn't get home until 4am so I hadn't read the script properly when I turned up at MGM to discuss it the next day, nursing a hangover.

Nevertheless, I agreed to do the pilot. A ten-second phone conversation between executives and that was it.

Napoleon Solo was the main role but there would be a small appearance by David McCallum - a young Scottish actor with a blond Beatle haircut - as Russian agent Illya Kuryakin. The role of Mr Allison, head of U.N.C.L.E., was played by a gruff actor named Will Kuluva.

The pilot, shot in 1963 when I was 31, got the green light, but before we started filming the series, a casting change was demanded. It's a story that illustrates the vagaries of Hollywood.

An NBC executive told my boss: 'The pilot's good. But you gotta get rid of one of the actors. What's his name . . . I can't remember. Something with a K, I think.'

My boss pondered. 'You mean Kuluva?' he asked, referring to Will Kuluva in the role of Mr Allison.

'Yeah, that's the guy. We don't like him. Find somebody else.'

Will was replaced by a classy Hollywood star, Leo Carroll - who'd been in pictures since the Thirties - in the newly named role of Mr Waverly.

The irony is that Will Kuluva was never supposed to be fired. The NBC executive was trying to recall the name of David McCallum's character, Kuryakin. It was 'that Russian guy with the long hair' that NBC wanted canned, not Kuluva.

Which explains the NBC executive's surprise when my boss later informed him that he'd hired the 71-year-old Leo to fill the role. 'Geez, isn't he too old for the part?' was the understandable response.

The show was soon a huge hit, getting 70,000 fan letters a month.

Many wanted U.N.C.L.E. ID cards, but a few wanted to offer us more intimate services. When riding in open cars, I was bombarded with house and apartment keys labelled with the addresses of the adoring girls who lived behind those doors.

At the end of our first season, I had to put up an electric fence around my house to keep out the girls. I even tried using recorded animal noises to fend off my visitors, but I could never operate the sound system.

Why McQueen gave me my first six-figure pay check

My friendship with Steve McQueen endured despite our antics on The Magnificent Seven. I enjoyed his company immensely and he evidently liked me, too.

By 1968, his career was in steady ascent: after The Magnificent Seven he'd starred in The Great Escape and The Sand Pebbles. He sent me the script for Bullitt, hoping I'd accept a role, and it was accompanied by a salary offer in line with my expectations.

The script dealt with the machinations of organised crime and big-time politics in San Francisco. Unfortunately, I found its mistaken identities, phoney clues, double crosses and betrayals so confusing that I was convinced several pages had gone missing.

A few days later, Steve called me. 'What do you think?' he asked.

'It doesn't make any sense. I can't follow the storyline even after reading it twice.'

'Hmm, that's a problem,' Steve said. 'What should I do?'

'Actually, I have a suggestion. I know someone who's a terrific script doctor - a British girl who has worked wonders with a lot of pictures. Why not give her a call?'

Steve followed my advice. The script doctor provided a long list of suggestions: scenes to delete and add; characters to simplify; motivations to explain.

The script was revised and the new version sent to me, along with a salary offer higher than the first.

Script problems: McQueen in Bullitt

However, when I read the script, I found only ten per cent of the doctor's suggestions had been followed. The story was practically as confusing as ever. I told Steve.

Dismayed, he sent the script back to his writing team again and again. Each time, they made changes and Steve passed the revised script to me, together with yet another salary offer, each one higher than the last.

Finally, I received a version of the script with a salary offer higher than any I'd received for a picture: my first six-figure movie payday.

The script wasn't much different from the first version I'd read months before. But when Steve called, I told him: 'You know, the picture is starting to look better and better to me!'

I figured I would let critics and audiences figure out the plot. I guess they did, since Bullitt was a box-office smash.

I remained friends with Steve until his death from lung cancer in 1980. Steve blamed asbestos from a ship he'd worked on aged 19, ignoring the fact that he'd smoked two or three packs of cigarettes and a lot of marijuana every day for years.

In August 1964, Steve and his first wife Neile had their first big Hollywood party. I was invited along with James Coburn, George Hamilton, the Kirk Douglases, Sharon Tate and Gena Rowlands.

It was a spectacular event, one that proclaimed the arrival of Steve and Neile McQueen as important figures in Hollywood. Around midnight, I found myself on the patio looking at the ocean.

Steve joined me and we had a chat. Then there was a long pause, not unusual in a conversation with Steve. Finally I said: 'When you were in New York in the Fifties, living in a cold-water flat and courting Neile on your bike, did you ever think you'd end up this way?'

There was another pause and without looking at me, Steve replied: 'What makes you think I'm going to end up this way now?'

After another pause he walked away. I'll always miss his unique way of looking at life.

London calling: Robert with Diana Rigg, Sir John Gielgud and Jill Bennet in Julius Caesar in England in 1969

Saving Jack Nicholson

After graduating in 1956, I was asked to stand in as a part-time teacher at a Los Angeles acting class.

Among the young hopefuls was a handsome stud from New Jersey with a strange accent. I remember that he tried to do a scene from the play Bus Stop, but somehow never had the confidence to carry it off.

His confidence problem was surprisingly long-lasting.

I remember him sitting on the floor of my dressing room one afternoon in 1967 and saying: 'Vaughnie, I'm going to give myself two more years in this business. Then I'll look for another way to make a living.'

'Hang in there, Jack,' I told him. 'You're too young to quit.'

A couple of years later, he demonstrated his skills in Easy Rider. The world still refers to him as Jack, as in Nicholson.

My whisky lunch with Bette

I was summoned at short notice to go to Bette Davis's Bel Air home to discuss a TV drama about a lawyer and his mother. I arrived promptly, assuming, based on the hour of the day, that we would be lunching. Not so.

Miss Davis did not rise when I entered the room but extended her hand. Before I could sit down, she pointed at the bottle of Scotch on the table and said in that raspy voice of hers: 'Help yourself.' I declined politely.

We chatted about showbusiness and politics and, increasingly famished, I ate what must have amounted to a pound of peanuts in a bowl next to the whisky.

At around 2pm, I looked about desperately for someone who would conduct us to a room to eat. No such luck.

So I decided to join Bette in the Scotch. The glasses were filled several times. I couldn't catch up with her but I gave it my best shot.

Around 3pm, after another round, Bette decided to tell me about her life but nothing about our project. Thanks to the drink, however, I no longer gave a damn.

An hour later, Bette announced that she had to get ready for an appointment at a hotel many miles from Bel Air. As I rose, she remarked: 'When I've changed, will you be so kind as to drive me to the hotel?'

I replied: 'Miss Davis, not only can't I drive you to the hotel, I can barely see you.'

For some reason, she thought my remark the epitome of wit. She laughed heartily and raised her hand graciously as I had seen her do in her film portrayals of royalty.

The TV drama was never made and Bette Davis and I never saw each other again.

Perfect Natalie ... and nights with Elvis and Sinatra

More than 50 years have passed but the memory of my first meeting with Natalie Wood in 1956 remains vivid.

Natalie was 17 and already a star for her performance with James Dean in Rebel Without A Cause. I was 23 and it was the opening night of a play in which I had a lead role.

If you've seen Natalie in a movie, you will know how beautiful she was - vulnerable and demure, with enormous brown eyes suggesting a combustible blend of innocence and passion.

That vulnerability was even greater off-camera; without make-up she looked the picture of childlike innocence.

There was a moment that evening after we touched hands (it really wasn't a handshake) that I knew we would see each other again - a moment confirmed a few minutes later when she asked my mother: 'Is your son seeing anyone?'

I don't know what my mother said because she was always benumbed in the presence of movie stars. But before the party broke up, I had Natalie's telephone number.

As we parted that night, Natalie said: 'If I don't get back to you, don't be discouraged. I may be off to New York to do a live television show with Dennis Hopper.'

I was relieved that she would be gone for a while since I had no money and was sharing a small room and a car with my mother.

Between the time Natalie left and her return, I was signed by Burt Lancaster's production company. I was working back-to-back as a guest star on many hit TV shows. If things could possibly get better for me, I didn't see how.

Suddenly there was light where there had been only shadows, and revelations where there had been only mysteries, and my sweet guide to these formerly unknown experiences was Natalie.

Movie studio doors were opened. I was now on the A-list for parties, rubbing shoulders with people named Rock and Rory and Tab and Troy - and suddenly my picture was being snapped along with theirs. The glow of celebrity was mostly reflected off Natalie, but I was basking in it nonetheless.

Natalie pictured with Robert in 1957

On several nights we dined at the Villa Capri restaurant in Hollywood where Natalie introduced me to Frank Sinatra.

I had seen him there before - it was a place where, for the price of a beer and if he was sufficiently involved with his friend Jack Daniels, I would hear that glorious voice toot out a few tunes accompanied by a slightly out-of-tune piano.

Oddly enough, Elvis Presley, who was a friend of Natalie's, became a kind of presence in our relationship.

We spent an evening at Pacific Ocean Park in Santa Monica as guests of Elvis. He had hired the amusement park for a party for his friends.

That is where Natalie and I, during a quiet interlude spent looking into the dark swirling ocean waters and sipping wine from paper cups, talked about our mutual fear of drowning.

It's a terribly chilling memory in light of what happened to her in 1981, when she drowned during a trip with her husband, Robert Wagner, on their yacht.

My friendship with Natalie was one of the most important of my young life. I think of her often. Of course, we took divergent paths in life. A year after we first met, Natalie married Robert Wagner.

Natalie occupies a special place in my memories. Luminous, lovely, exciting, glamorous, she was all those things.

But for me she was above all a sweet and generous young woman whose friendship meant - and means - so very much to me.

In BBC's Hustle flanked by (left to right) Marc Warren, Adrian Lester, Robert Glenister and Jaime Murray

Hustle and bustle

I get hundreds of scripts every year and usually can't get past the tenth page. But when I read the first Hustle script, then the second, then the third, I thought: 'This is really something different.'

Arrangements for the first shoot in 2004 were very last-minute and I arrived in London three days late. The Press were keen to find out what research I had done for the series about a team of con artists. Of course, I hadn't had time, so I made something up.

What if Napoleon Solo, my Man From U.N.C.L.E. character, retired on his small secret agent pension but had become too used to the good life and the excitement? What would he be tempted to do?

The Hustle team are on series five now. I've learned nothing about con tricks, except that they involve many talented people. There's lots of jargon, which is fun - I am a roper, somebody who pulls in the wealthy victim. I wonder if Napoleon would really approve?

 A Fortunate Life, by Robert Vaughn, is published by JR Books at 18.99. To order your copy for 17.10 inc p&p, call the Review Bookstore on 0845 155 0713.

NEXT WEEK: Why I believe Aristotle Onassis was behind the murder of my friend Bobby Kennedy
